page.lettertext:
Belgia 1589 2 August To M
r
Secretary
It may please yo
r
H. by my former l
re
s unto yo
u
& by
e
inclosed to my
L. Treasorer
I have written about
e Articles
w
ch
were sent unto me from hir
Ma
ty
& because I suppose
yt wilbe im
ted unto yo
u
I will not trouble yo
r
H. to
heare yt repeated, my
L.Willughbyes
answer to
e placcart
is come to many mens hand
in these countreys both in French & in
Flemishe,
Barnevelt
himselfe hath shewed yt in counsell
& declared
t
yf he mighte be
mitted, he would reply in
such sort as not onely these contreys but all
England
&
oth
r
places shall talk of
e matt
r
. Howbeyt
e
counsell
gave
no answer to him, nor uttred any token of liking or
disliking, But I would my L. could have liked to have
made some of us
t
ar heer acquainted, w
th
his purpose
before
e book had bin published we could have put him in
minde of sondry very necessary point
w
ch
are ill omitted
tending to his owne defence & theyr reproche. I think yo
r
H ys adv
r
tised of
e
Count Hohenloes
coming hether, I cannot
ceave yf he was publickely honored, & [.] yt ys supposed
he came not of him self, The most of those w
th
whom I
have talked ar of opinion
t
he hath bin moved to returne
by some private
sons who desyre to have
e marriage
concluded between
e
Countesse of Bueren
& him th
r
by to
encrese
e Nobility of
is countrye. & to make theyr
ticular
ty strong w
th
his friendship. Ther ys also a speech
t
he
hath l
re
s from
e
K of Denm
r
ke
e
D. of Saxony
& some
oth
r
princes of
Germany
to hir Ma
ty
, to what effect I cannot
learne, but yt hath bin bruted
t
they are to request of her
Ma
tye
a favorable hearing of those causes in w
ch
he hath bin
touched in
es countreyes, wheruppon the report hath gon w
th
in
these four daies
t
he would dispatche a gentleman to hir Ma
ty
w
ch
yet I und
r
stand ys not greatly liked of by some
t
ar here
He ys de
ted this daye toward
Gorchum
to
Count Maurice
for
t
the Ennemy ys sayd to have made his approches to
Huesden.
It ys und
r
stood
is day from
Schenck
that
e 28 of
is
last
moneth he encountred w
th
e Ennemy, marching
toward
frieseland,
about
Haltern
one
e borders of
Wesphayle
& defeated 7 Ensignes of footemen & 3 cornet
of Horse
w
ch
he put all to
e sword, but
t
then escaped about
e
nomb
r
of 40 horsemen, & as he himself writeth his bootye
of Jewells, plate mony & oth
r
things of price was very ritche
fol.60v
besydes 500 horse of one sort & other w
ch
he caried awaie
of his owne companies ther was not one slayne yn
e
Conflict, nor more then three hurt,
t
died shortly after
& thus I take &c. Au
g
2. 89
